Description: common name of pest or pathogen
scientific name of pest or pathogen
tree species affected by pest/pathogen (may be multiple)
indicates whether pest/pathogen is native or exotic
Geographic origin of pest/pathogen, if known. Typically only indicated for exotic species.
Year in which exotic pest/pathogen was introduced to North America
Status in Virginia Blue Ridge Ecoregion (as of last update of the record).
Variable.Codes: in order from most to least likely to be currently impacting trees in the region: current; nascent = warning by the feds, state scientists, or a scientific publication that it could cause damage locally in the near future. I only listed as nascent if a reliable source specifically purposed watching out for it in the future; possible = exists nearby and has the ability to infest local forests; potential = exists somewhere in the US and feeds on similar tree species

Description: Location within or near Virginia in which the pest or pathogen was first detected
Year in which exotic pest/pathogen was detected at the location identified in Virginia_source field.
Year in which pest/pathogen was first detected in Shenandoah National Park. Applies to exotic pests/pathogens or outbreaks of natives pests/pathogens.
Notes on detection of pest/pathogen at Shenandoah National Park
Year in which pest/pathogen was first detected at the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute. Applies to exotic pests/pathogens or outbreaks of natives pests/pathogens.
Type of detection at Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI)
Notes on detection of pest/pathogen at Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute (SCBI)
Sources of information on the pest/patogen. These are often informal/ refer to internal documents (contact us for more info).
